item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Drone Again Hits a Moscow Building Housing Russian Ministries
item.description: Ukrainian officials have become more open in their view that targets inside Russia are legitimate.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: France Prepares Niger Evacuation Amid Risks of Conflict
item.description: Tensions were rising in the West African nation over demands by African and Western countries to reinstate a president ousted in a military takeover.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Elian Peltier and Dionne Searcey
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Security forces launched tear gas to disperse a pro-junta protest outside the French Embassy in Niamey, the capital of Niger, on Sunday.

item.title: Russia’s Law Targeting Transgender People Sows Fear for L.G.B.T. Russians
item.description: A new law underscores how Vladimir V. Putin is increasingly using the war in Ukraine as justification for greater restrictions on L.G.B.T.Q. life, portraying it as a consequence of deviant Western values.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Georgy Birger

item.title: Mexico’s ‘Monster’ Trucks Show Cartels Taking Drug War to Next Level
item.description: Taking the monster truck concept to deadly new realms, cartels are modifying pickups with gun turrets, steel armoring and battering rams.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed armored vehicle that had been used by the Jalisco New Generation Cartel, a powerful Mexican criminal group.

item.title: U.K.’s New Alcohol Taxes Are Aimed at Keeping Pubs Open and Votes Flowing
item.description: The changes are the biggest shake-up to Britain’s alcohol levies in 140 years, according to a government whose leader was clearly on the campaign trail in announcing them.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak pulling a pint of stout at the Great British Beer Festival in London on Tuesday.

item.title: 2 Drone Strikes in Moscow in 2 Days and a Message: Russia Is Not Safe
item.description: The same building housing Russian government offices was hit twice within 48 hours.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko, Alina Lobzina and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: A building in central Moscow was struck by a drone on Tuesday for the second time in 48 hours.

item.title: Ousmane Sonko’s Arrest Sets Off New Round of Protests
item.description: Ousmane Sonko, a fiery figure with a loyal youth following, was charged with fomenting insurrection, and his party dissolved.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Dionne Searcey
item.media:description: A police officer detaining a protester during clashes with supporters of Senegal’s opposition leader Ousmane Sonko on Monday in Dakar.

item.title: Under Hindu Nationalist Leaders, Sectarian Violence Flares in India
item.description: A gunman who killed Muslim train passengers and a Hindu march that turned riotous underscore how the partisan stances of India’s top Hindu leaders have given license to chaotic elements in the country.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Relatives of a man who was killed in clashes in Haryana State, India, carrying his body on a stretcher at a hospital in Nuh on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Grain Lifeline in Danube Ports Comes Under Russia Threat
item.description: Since the collapse of the Black Sea grain deal two weeks ago, small ports on the Danube River are the only shipping outlet for millions of tons of grain.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The bulk carrier TQ Samsun transiting the Bosporus last month in Istanbul. The TQ Samsun was the last grain ship, carrying corn and rapeseed, to leave Ukraine under the Black Sea grain initiative before Russia halted the program.

item.title: UNESCO Recommends Venice for Endangered List
item.description: The United Nations’ culture agency is warning of twin perils to the historic city from mass tourism and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venice’s grand canal. A former government minister said the city had been “fragile,” but was now well placed to face its challenges.

item.title: Construction to Break German Dependence on Russian Gas Hits a Snag: Wartime Bombs
item.description: The choreography of finding and clearing unexploded, decades-old munitions has become routine on Germany’s northern coast.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: The liquefied natural gas terminal being built in Wilhelmshaven, in northern Germany, in December.

item.title: ‘Barbenheimer’ Isn’t Funny in Nuclear-Scarred Japan
item.description: The Japanese subsidiary of Warner Bros. criticized what it called insensitive promotion of “Barbie” by the company’s headquarters.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: A movie theater featuring the films “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” in Los Angeles.

item.title: Aung San Suu Kyi Receives Partial Pardon in Myanmar
item.description: The civilian leader, who was ousted in a coup in 2021, had six years cut from a 33-year prison sentence and five of her 19 convictions overturned, state television said.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Aung San Suu Kyi delivering a speech in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, in 2020.

item.title: Kerala Lottery: India Sanitation Workers Win $1.2 Million Lottery
item.description: The winners, who are sanitation co-workers in India, each make just a few dollars a day. The jackpot will help them pay off crippling debts.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj and Mike Ives
item.media:description: A lottery ticket vendor selling tickets in Kochi, Kerala State, India, last year.

item.title: Kenya Offers to Lead International Force to Help Restore Order in Haiti
item.description: Kenya has offered to lead a police force to help restore order to Haiti, where gangs that control vast parts of the country’s capital have fomented violence.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Tires were set on fire by the police during a protest in January in Port-au-Prince after a gang attack on a police station that left six officers dead.

item.title: Iran Orders Two-Day Shutdown Because of ‘Unprecedented’ Heat
item.description: The government announced a two-day public holiday, ordering all government agencies, banks and schools to close amid soaring temperatures that threatened public health and strained the power grid.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: In Iran’s capital, Tehran, the temperature was expected to reach 104 degrees Fahrenheit (40 Celsius) in the coming days, the country’s metrological organization said.

item.title: Chinese Zoo: This Is a Real Sun Bear, Not a Costume
item.description: “Some people think I look too human when I stand up,” the Hangzhou Zoo’s statement said, after a video prompted internet conspiracy theories. “I am a Malayan sun bear!”
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas and Chang Che

item.title: A Stairway to Nowhere Sells for $32,000 in London
item.description: An entrepreneur saw what others didn’t and now owns the unused set of stairs, which are attached to the back of a suburban building.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: An enclosed stairwell attached to a building in suburban London was sold at auction on Tuesday. Its new owner envisions the space as potentially housing desks for entrepreneurs.

item.title: Solar Supply Chain Grows More Opaque Amid Human Rights Concerns
item.description: The global industry is cutting some ties to China, but its exposure to forced labor remains high and companies are less transparent, a new report found.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Ivan Penn
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: A JA Solar factory in Hefei, China. A new report found that major solar companies, including JA Solar, are likely to still have extensive exposure to China’s Xinjiang region and potentially to forced labor there.

item.title: Typhoon Khanun Threatens Japan and China on Heels of Doksuri
item.description: Typhoon Khanun was barreling through the Pacific days after an earlier tropical cyclone, Doksuri, brought death and destruction to the region.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Hikari Hida and Amy Chang Chien

item.title: Move Over, Men: Women Were Hunters, Too
item.description: Anthropologists are finding that women in modern foraging societies have played a major role in catching game.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The details of Ukraine’s drone strikes.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Ukraine Steps Up Growing Campaign to Strike Within Russia
item.description: The stepped-up drone and missile attacks show a will to hamper the Kremlin’s military logistics, and to remind ordinary Russians of the cost of war.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A house destroyed by shelling in the Russian-controlled region of Donetsk, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Missing Sailor Donald Lawson’s Boat Is Found Off the Mexican Coast
item.description: Donald Lawson, 41, of Baltimore was training for a solo sailing trip around the world when he left Acapulco on July 5. His capsized boat, the Defiant, was found in the Pacific on July 24.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:credit: Kim Hairston/The Baltimore Sun, via Tribune News Service, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Donald Lawson hoped to become one of the few African Americans to set world records in the sport of sailing. His wife said she last heard from him on July 12.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Floods Pummel Beijing
item.description: Also, evidence shows that Myanmar’s junta has increased its brutal attacks against civilians.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Villagers gathered in the Mentougou District in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Drone Attacks on Russia Show Evidence of Ukraine’s Other Counteroffensive
item.description: Officials in Ukraine rarely discuss attacks on targets inside Russia, including Moscow. But video evidence shows an increasing effort to launch long-range strikes inside the country.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis, Yelyzaveta Kovtun and Alexander Cardia

item.title: ISIS Affiliate Claims Deadly Attack at Political Rally in Pakistan
item.description: The death toll from Sunday’s suicide bombing, which targeted a political rally near the border with Afghanistan, rose to at least 54 people, an official said.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Security personnel examining the site of an explosion in the Bajaur district near Pakistan’s border with Afghanistan on Monday.

item.title: At Least 5 People Killed in a Palestinian Refugee Camp in Lebanon
item.description: Rival factions have been fighting for three days, at times with heavy weaponry, in the densely populated Ein al-Hilweh camp in the coastal city of Sidon, south of Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: Smoke rose during clashes between rival factions in the Palestinian refugee camp of Ein al-Hilweh near the southern port city of Sidon, Lebanon, on Monday.

item.title: Extensive Minefields Impede Ukraine’s Counteroffensive, Military Experts Say
item.description: Russia has been using antitank weaponry against the Ukrainian forces’ mine clearing vehicles, an analyst said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with the 35th Marine Brigade outside the village of Makarivka, Ukraine, last week.

item.title: Mysterious Object Found on Australian Beach Is Identified as Space Debris
item.description: A cylindrical object that was found in remote Western Australia probably came from an Indian rocket, Australia’s space agency said.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A cylindrical object found on a beach in Australia this month prompted widespread speculation over its origin.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Will Host Talks About Ukraine’s Peace Plan, Diplomats Say
item.description: Envoys from nations including the United States, Brazil, China and India have been invited, but it was not clear who would attend, the diplomats said.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Members of Ukraine’s 80th Air Assault Brigade firing rockets during an operation in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine in May.

item.title: Wagner Mercenary Group Will Stop Recruiting, New Recording Says
item.description: The recording, purportedly of the group’s founder, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, appeared to signal that the mercenary force would continue operations but on a smaller scale.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The future of Russia’s Wagner private military company has been in question since its founder, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, called off a short-lived mutiny in June.

item.title: Eleven Are Dead and 27 Missing as Heavy Rains Batter Beijing
item.description: Landslides and flash flooding have threatened outer districts of the city, and more than 52,000 residents were evacuated from their homes, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: A man in rain gear and with an umbrella crosses a street in Beijing, on Monday.

item.title: Israel’s Justice Minister Is the Brains Behind Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is the face of his government’s effort to reduce judicial power. His justice minister, Yariv Levin, is the main architect.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Yariv Levin, Israel’s justice minister, has been the main champion of the judicial overhaul by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, right.

item.title: Russia’s Wartime Spending Raises Fears of an Economic Bubble
item.description: The economic strength has helped to maintain popular support for Vladimir Putin’s war, but some have warned the state-led spending is threatening the country’s financial stability.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow this month. A state-led spending boom has propped up Russia’s economy, despite the country facing the most far-reaching campaign of sanctions imposed by Western nations in modern history.

item.title: Who Paid for a Mysterious Spy Tool? The FBI, an FBI Inquiry Found.
item.description: After a Times report, the bureau canceled its contract with a government contractor that used the tool on its behalf. But questions remain.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Ronen Bergman and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A branch of the hacking firm NSO in Sapir, Israel. The Biden administration put the company on a Commerce Department blacklist in 2021.

item.title: Moscow’s attacks are stoking hatred of Russia in Odesa.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: U.S. Nurse and Her Child Are Kidnapped in Haiti
item.description: This, along with other recent kidnappings, may signal the end of a brief respite, as gangs tighten their grip after being targets of vigilante violence.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Alix Dorsainvil, the group’s community nurse and the wife of the group’s director, Sandro Dorsainvil.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Drone attacks in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: An office building in Moscow after a drone attack on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Dozens Dead in Pakistan
item.description: Also, Narendra Modi’s silence on Manipur and Iraq’s climate destruction.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: People carried coffins to collect bodies of victims outside a hospital following a blast in Bajaur, Pakistan, on Sunday.

item.title: Niger Coup: West African Leaders Impose Sanctions and Threaten Military Action
item.description: A demand for a restoration of democracy echoed calls by the United States and France, major security allies of Niger.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
item.media:description: Protesting the French military’s presence outside the French Embassy in Niamey, Nigeria, on Sunday.

item.title: Blast at Political Rally in Pakistan Kills at Least 43 and Wounds 200
item.description: An explosion at a political rally on Sunday in northwest Pakistan killed dozens of people and injured 200 more, officials said, the latest sign of the deteriorating security situation in Pakistan, where some militant groups have become more active over the past two years.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Outside a hospital on Sunday after an explosion in Bajaur, a district in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province near Pakistan’s border with Afghanistan.

item.title: Ukraine Recaptures Staromaiorske, a Glimmer of Success for Counteroffensive
item.description: Recapturing the village of Staromaiorske was such welcome news for the country that President Volodymyr Zelensky announced it himself. But formidable Russian defenses have stymied progress elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall

item.title: Russian Propaganda on Ukraine Appears in Minecraft and Other Video Games
item.description: Propaganda is appearing in Minecraft and other popular games and discussion groups as the Kremlin tries to win over new audiences.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Kellen Browning
item.media:description: In the Russian version of the World of Tanks video game, a recreation of the Soviet Union’s parade of tanks in Moscow in 1945.

item.title: Nero’s Theater Believed to Be Found in Rome
item.description: A dig at a palace set to become a hotel has unearthed traces of a theater that archaeologists hypothesize was built by Nero, the emperor with a disputed reputation for tyranny and debauchery.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: An archaeological dig at a Renaissance palazzo in Rome brought to light traces of the first-century theater that Emperor Nero built to indulge his inner artist.

item.title: Israeli Court Ruling May Determine Democracy’s Fate
item.description: From Hungary to India to Brazil, how judges responded to attacks on their independence helped decide whether would-be autocrats prevailed in constraining the courts.
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon
item.media:description: Demonstrators blocking traffic Monday on a highway in Tel Aviv during a protest against plans by Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to overhaul the country’s judicial system.

item.title: Could the Conflict in Manipur Become an Issue Modi Cannot Ignore?
item.description: India’s opposition is trying to force the prime minister to address the violence in Manipur, which has killed more than 150 people and displaced 60,000 others.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed house in the Churachandpur district of Manipur State, where widespread clashes began in early May.

item.title: ‘We Are a Romantic Country’: On the Set of a Steamy Hit in Italy
item.description: Italy falls for “Mare Fuori,” a television melodrama about the inmates of a juvenile detention center who pass the time making out — when not scowling at or occasionally stabbing one another.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fans of the “Mare Fuori” television series cheering as Massimiliano Caiazzo, one of the show’s stars, left the set this month in Naples, Italy.

item.title: Russia Says Ukrainian Drones Hit Moscow Buildings in Latest Attacks
item.description: The strike was the third in the past week in Moscow, a sign of how no city in Russia or Ukraine appears to be safe from the war. Russia blamed Ukraine, which has yet to comment.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: An office building in Moscow after a drone attack on Sunday.

item.title: A Climate Warning from the Cradle of Civilization
item.description: How extreme temperatures and dwindling water are pushing the Fertile Crescent toward the brink.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Bryan Denton
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times

item.title: Ancient Worms Revived From Permafrost After 46,000 Years
item.description: Scientists want to understand how the worms survived in extreme conditions for extraordinarily long periods of time.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquin
item.media:credit: Alexei V. Tchesunov and Anastasia Shatilovich/Institute of Physicochemical and Biological Problems in Soil Science RAS, via Reuters
item.media:description: A scanning electron picture of a female Panagrolaimus kolymaensis nematode roundworm.

item.title: Colombian President’s Son Is Arrested in Money Laundering Inquiry
item.description: The arrest of Nicolás Petro poses another test for President Gustavo Petro, who has struggled to push many of his reforms through a divided Congress.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Nicolás Petro, right, and his father, Gustavo Petro, the Colombian president, in Bogotá, Colombia, in 2022. The younger Mr. Petro was arrested on money laundering charges on Saturday.

item.title: Biden Presses Ahead With Effort to Broker Israeli-Saudi Deal
item.description: The president sent Jake Sullivan, his national security adviser, on the latest diplomatic mission seeking to forge ties between Saudi Arabia and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Ronen Bergman
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, returned to Saudi Arabia on a diplomatic mission, his second such trip in recent months.

item.title: U.S. Hunts Chinese Malware That Could Disrupt American Military Operations
item.description: American intelligence officials believe the malware could give China the power to disrupt or slow American deployments or resupply operations, including during a Chinese move against Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A fighter jet taking off from Andersen Air Force Base in Guam earlier this year. The Chinese code, the officials say, appears directed at ordinary utilities that often serve both civilian populations and nearby military bases.

item.title: A Sense of Mission at Risk as Israeli Reservists Resign to Protest New Law
item.description: Military reservists are key to Israel’s defense capacity and a shared sense of national mission. But scores of reservists have resigned over a new law curbing judicial power, reflecting a widening rift in Israeli society.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Israeli military reservists protested near the Ministry of Defense in Tel Aviv last week against plans to overhaul the judicial system.

item.title: Russia Strikes Ukrainian Grain Terminal, Kyiv Says
item.description: In St. Petersburg, President Vladimir V. Putin rejected calls for reviving a Black Sea grain deal or for ending fighting.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ukrainian port of Odesa, which has been regularly targeted since Russia pulled out of a deal to allow grain exports from Ukraine through the Black Sea.

item.title: Trudeau Reshuffles His Cabinet
item.description: Canada’s prime minister revamped his cabinet, demoting some ministers and reassigning key portfolios to get in fighting form for an election.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau during a news conference on Wednesday with cabinet ministers behind him at Rideau Hall in Ottawa.

item.title: In Odesa, Attacks Stoke Hatred of Russia
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia views Odesa as a culturally important part of his nation. But many in the Ukrainian city reject the connection and view the country that has been attacking it with loathing.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: Wildfires and Heat Transform Italy and Greece Into Tourism Nightmares
item.description: Record heat and wildfires have turned summer holidays into nightmares and called into question the future of cherished tourist destinations.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alberto Lo Bianco/LaPresse, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Residents watched a fire sweep across a hillside near Palermo in Sicily on Wednesday.

item.title: Coups in Africa Run Coast to Coast After Niger Turmoil
item.description: This past week’s military takeover in Niger completed a domino chain of countries ruled by leaders who seized power by force, fueling instability and presenting a conundrum for the United States.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Supporters of the military coup celebrating in Niamey, Niger, on Thursday.

item.title: Wildfires Are Displacing Canada’s Indigenous Communities
item.description: The country’s record-breaking fire season has led tens of thousands of Indigenous people to flee their homes and ravaged forests they rely on for sustenance.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald, Matt Joycey and Ben Laffin
item.media:credit: Matt Joycey for The New York Times
